q:
What will be the output of the following Javascript code?
Code:

(function () 
{
    try 
    {
        throw new Error("hackerearth");
    } 
    catch (h1) 
    {
        var h1 = 31, h2 = 33;
        console.log(h2);
    }
    console.log(h1);
    console.log(h2);
})();

Options:

  1. 33
undefined
33
  2. 33
31
33
  3. 33
undefined
undefined
  4. The code gives a run-time error

You were given a task to write a code for string reversal, you made a function and tried to run your code. On running the code an error occurs saying "error: cannot find ‘…’ in scope".

Which of the following is not a cause of such an error?

Suppose there is a product which is subdivided into two kinds: food and thing. Anything that is eatable is food else it is a thing. Let the product be the class with enumerations defined as food and thing. By default, the kind variable will be a thing.

Using the canEat() function, the kind will be changed to food for each instance. The name of the instance is “banana”. Now, choose the best suitable option from below with respect to the mentioned scenario.

Options

1.

kind variable has the function scope
product class has the class scope
canEat() class has the class scope

2.

kind variable has the class scope
product class has the class scope
canEat() class has the class scope

3.

kind variable has the class scope
product class has the global scope
canEat() class has the function scope

4.

kind variable has the global scope
product class has the global scope
canEat() class has the function scope
You are writing a program. There is a variable, let's call it "kind" that needs to be accessed/modified by all member functions. What should be the scope of this variable?

a.option: should be defined in all functions separately

q:
In Go, which of the following statements about a global variable is correct:

  1. Global variables are defined outside the function usually at the beginning of the code.
  2. These variables will hold their value throughout the lifetime of the program.
  3. After declaring a global variable, you can use it throughout the program.

a.option:
Statement 3 is incorrect
Statements 1 and 2 are correct

Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect 
Statement 3 is correct

Statement 1 is correct 
Statements 2 and 3
are incorrect

q:
What is the output of the following JavaScript snippet:

Code

var demo = 10; 
alert(demo + ", " + demo2 );
var demo2 = 20; 

var example = 53; 
var example2; 
alert(example + ", " + example2);
example2= 70; 

var declare = 36; 
declare2 = 62;
alert(declare + ", " + declare2); 
var declare2;

var half = 49; 
alert(half + ", " + half2);
var half2; 
half2= 84;

Output

1. 

10, 20
undefined, 53
36, undefined
49, 84

2. 

undefined, 20
53, undefined
36, 62 
49, 84

3. 

10, undefined
53, undefined
36, 62
49, undefined

4. 

10, 20
53, 70
36, undefined
undefined, 84

Which of the following Javascript code snippets will produce an error?


1. 

console.log(typeof x);
if (1==1) 
{
    let x = "abc";
}



2.

if (1==1) 
{
    console.log(typeof x);
    let x = "abc";
}



3. 

if (1==1) 
{
    let x = "abc";
    console.log(typeof x);
}

What is the output of the following C code:

    #include<stdio.h>
    int X=400;
    int main()
    {
        int X=200;
        printf("%d\n", X);
        return 0;
    }
In Go, which of the following entities are used to declare variables?

a.option: Local variable, hybrid variable, and function parameters
Global variable, arrays, and informal parameters
Local variable, global variable, and formal parameters
